intro: Tanacetum galae, commonly known as the Galician tansy, is a perennial herb native to Central and Eastern Europe. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lance-shaped leaves that are finely toothed and emit a strong, camphor-like scent. Its flowers are yellow and arranged in flat-topped clusters, attracting various pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Tanacetum galae is often found in moist meadows and along riverbanks, where it thrives in well-drained, loamy soils.
